Parades
ONE OF the most colorful parts of
a parade is the band; indeed, if we must
get right down to it, it is the parade.
Marching in the forefront, it is the focus
of attention and admiration.
If it's a good band, it sets a good pace
and the marchers willingly follow its
inspiring leadership. On the other hand,
if it is incompetent to lead rousingly, the
whole glittering display is spiritless, the
parade is a flop, and the onlookers are
disappointed.
A good campus newspaper should always be abreast and even a little ahead
of the current of campus life, attempting
to recognize trends in advance and to
articulate tangible opinions upon them, in
an effort to keep every one in step and
heading toward a definite goal.
The march of campus events during
the next year promises to be interesting
and significant. We expect to contribute
as much as possible to it. If we are
equal to the occasion we will have the
approval of spectators; if not, we deserve
whatever we get.
Anyway, we love a parade.

—and Policies
TRADITION demands that when a
new staff takes over the operation of the
NEWS-LETTER that it indicate the attitude which it expects to assume during
its regime. Accordingly, we commit
ourselves as follows:
We do not propose to take any stand
on possible campus questions in advance,
simply because if we are predisposed to
certain sentiments we will not be able to
appraise the true significance of later
events in an unbiased manner. We intend, however, to take definite stands as
the occasions arise.
Our purpose is to make the paper more
representative of campus attitudes than
it has been heretofore. In accordance
with this we solicit the expression of
student opinion through our letter column.
In a word, we will be frank and openminded in all our criticisms and suggestions.

Live And Learn
RECENTLY, Bill Triplett made the
report that the Honor System had been
found effective. That sounded like good
news for Hopkins men—all our worries
over.
If Bill had stopped there it would have
been all right; that is to say, the psychological effect of his statement might have
been soothing. But he didn't. He went
on to point out that the effectiveness of
the system is proven by the fact that
more men have been tried for violations
of the code following its recent revision
than ever before.
That was somewhat of a jolt. We always thought that the measure of the
successfulness of an honor system was
the extent to which men were governed

has reached our ears is the fact that
the Turnbulls are going to discontinue their Sunday night parties.

S. C. To Pass On Affair
It was revealed that under the
new regulations passed this college
year, the Student Council must pass
on all class expenditures.
In addition to having built up one
of the finest orchestras in the country, Isham Jones is a composer of
popular melodies second to none.
Only several years after he entered
into the dance band business he was
signed up for College Inn, in Chicago. His popularity has spread
rapidly.
In 1930 he began moving East.
At Atlantic City's Hotel Ambassador large crowds packed the ballroom in which his band was featured. He has invaded New York
and is now making a big hit. The
Columbia chain recently increased
the number of hours on the air.
in their actions by principles of gentlemanly honor. It simply never occurred
to us that the more men seen cheating,
the more certain one could be that the
spirit of "honor" was slowly but surely
extending its influence.
Oh, well. Life is full of surprises.

Correction
In the February 10 issue of the NEWSLETTER, it was incorrectly stated that
Mr. William Gates, president of the
Maya Society, was a research assistant
at the Johns Hopkins. Mr. Gates is a
research associate at the University. The
NEWS-LETTER regrets the error.

Wrestling Recognized

The Hopkins wrestling team,
which has been unofficially in existence for several years, has aroused
much interest in the sport, and due
to this popularity the A. A. Board
throught it only fair to give the
team official recognition. The members of the wrestling team who have
participated in seventy-five percent
of the matches will be awarded the
minor "H".

colleges during the past week. After
severely trouncing Gallaudet College, 27-0, the Jay team traveled to
Western Maryland, where they beat
the Terrors by a 28-10 score.

straight win as he led his charges

The Oriental girl reclines on a sheet of plate

glass supported by two slaves. The magician
waves a white sheet in front of the pretty
maiden ... pronounces a few magic words ...
Presto! She has disappeared in thin air.

EXPLANATION:
"Disappearing" acts are among the most popular in the repertory of the magician. Dogs,
horses, girls, whole rooms disappear—whisked
into wings, dropped through trapdoors, hidden
by mirrors. But this "disappearance" is a bit
different.One of the"slaves"is a hollow dummy.
When the magician holds up the sheet the lithe
little lady disappears completely—into the con-

venient figure of the dummy.

DE MOLAYS TO DISCUSS
DANCE PLANS TODAY
At the regular meeting of the DeMolay Club, to be held at 12:20 today in Room B, Levering Hall,
plans for future activities of the
club will be decided upon.
Final plans for a dance to be held
shortly after the spring vacation will
be drawn up, and the advisability of
having a father and son banquet will
be discussed. It is urged that all
members of the club be present.

Barnstormers To Hold
Dance Tomorrow Night
The Barnstormers, dramatic organization of the Johns Hopkins,
will hold a semi-formal dance at
9 p. m. tomorrow in the barn. Admission is restricted to members of
the group and their friends.
At the present time, the Barnstormers are contemplating several
radical changes in regard to the
time, place, and type of their annual play, which has hitherto been
presented at the Lyric Theatre befor the Christmas vacation.

Parades
ONE OF the most colorful parts of
a parade is the band; indeed, if we must
get right down to it, it is the parade.
Marching in the forefront, it is the focus
of attention and admiration.
If it's a good band, it sets a good pace
and the marchers willingly follow its
inspiring leadership. On the other hand,
if it is incompetent to lead rousingly, the
whole glittering display is spiritless, the
parade is a flop, and the onlookers are
disappointed.
A good campus newspaper should always be abreast and even a little ahead
of the current of campus life, attempting
to recognize trends in advance and to
articulate tangible opinions upon them, in
an effort to keep every one in step and
heading toward a definite goal.
The march of campus events during
the next year promises to be interesting
and significant. We expect to contribute
as much as possible to it. If we are
equal to the occasion we will have the
approval of spectators; if not, we deserve
whatever we get.
Anyway, we love a parade.

—and Policies
TRADITION demands that when a
new staff takes over the operation of the
NEWS-LETTER that it indicate the attitude which it expects to assume during
its regime. Accordingly, we commit
ourselves as follows:
We do not propose to take any stand
on possible campus questions in advance,
simply because if we are predisposed to
certain sentiments we will not be able to
appraise the true significance of later
events in an unbiased manner. We intend, however, to take definite stands as
the occasions arise.
Our purpose is to make the paper more
representative of campus attitudes than
it has been heretofore. In accordance
with this we solicit the expression of
student opinion through our letter column.
In a word, we will be frank and openminded in all our criticisms and suggestions.

RECENTLY, Bill Triplett made the
report that the Honor System had been
found effective. That sounded like good
news for Hopkins men—all our worries
over.
If Bill had stopped there it would have
been all right; that is to say, the psychological effect of his statement might have
been soothing. But he didn't. He went
on to point out that the effectiveness of
the system is proven by the fact that
more men have been tried for violations
of the code following its recent revision
than ever before.
That was somewhat of a jolt. We always thought that the measure of the
successfulness of an honor system was
the extent to which men were governed

Wrestling Recognized

The Hopkins wrestling team,
which has been unofficially in existence for several years, has aroused
much interest in the sport, and due
to this popularity the A. A. Board
throught it only fair to give the
team official recognition. The members of the wrestling team who have
participated in seventy-five percent
of the matches will be awarded the
minor "H".

The Oriental girl reclines on a sheet of plate

glass supported by two slaves. The magician
waves a white sheet in front of the pretty
maiden ... pronounces a few magic words ...
Presto! She has disappeared in thin air.

EXPLANATION:
"Disappearing" acts are among the most popular in the repertory of the magician. Dogs,
horses, girls, whole rooms disappear—whisked
into wings, dropped through trapdoors, hidden
by mirrors. But this "disappearance" is a bit
different.One of the"slaves"is a hollow dummy.
When the magician holds up the sheet the lithe
little lady disappears completely—into the con-

venient figure of the dummy.

DE MOLAYS TO DISCUSS
DANCE PLANS TODAY
At the regular meeting of the DeMolay Club, to be held at 12:20 today in Room B, Levering Hall,
plans for future activities of the
club will be decided upon.
Final plans for a dance to be held
shortly after the spring vacation will
be drawn up, and the advisability of
having a father and son banquet will
be discussed. It is urged that all
members of the club be present.

Barnstormers To Hold
Dance Tomorrow Night
The Barnstormers, dramatic organization of the Johns Hopkins,
will hold a semi-formal dance at
9 p. m. tomorrow in the barn. Admission is restricted to members of
the group and their friends.
At the present time, the Barnstormers are contemplating several
radical changes in regard to the
time, place, and type of their annual play, which has hitherto been
presented at the Lyric Theatre befor the Christmas vacation.

Irrenstalt, Berlin, to the Liberal
Club on Monday, March 13.

scientific study to find out, if we could,
the kind of tobacco best suited for pipes.
Down in the Blue Grass regions of
Kentucky, we found a tobacco called
White Burley. There is a grade of this
tobacco between the kind used for chewing and the varieties suitable for cigarettes
that is best suited for pipes. This tobacco
is used in Granger.
This tobacco is prepared by a method
worked out many years ago by Mr. J. N.

Wellman. It gives Granger a fragrance
and mellowness that pipe smokers like,
and makes it burn to a clean, dry ash.
Granger never gums a pipe.
Granger has not been on sale very long,
but it has come to be popular, and there
is this much about it: We have yet to
know of a man who started smoking it,
who didn't keep on. Folks seem to like it.
